definition: cancel an event or agreement.
example: they held a ballot on whether to call off industrial action

definition: order a person or dog to stop attacking someone.
example: Gunda pleaded with him to call the dog off

definition: pay a visit to someone.
example: he's planning to call on Katherine today

definition: make use of someone or something as a source of help.
example: we are able to call on academic staff with a wide variety of expertise

definition: perform a task.
example: we're carrying out a market research survey

definition: happen, take place.
example: can you tell us more about how the project came about?

definition: (of a ship) change direction.
example: the boat came about and headed south along the river shore

definition: meet or find someone or something by chance.
example: I came across these old photos recently

definition: (of a person) appear or sound in a specified way, give a specified impression.
example: he'd always come across as a decent guy

definition: hand over or provide what is wanted.
example: she has come across with some details

definition: (of an issue, situation, or problem) occur or present itself, especially unexpectedly.
example: the subject has not yet come up

definition: become brighter in a specified way as a result of being polished or cleaned.
example: I cleaned up the painting and it came up like new

definition: begin one's studies at a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge.
example: she came up to Oxford to read History

definition: cause something to fall by cutting it through at the base.
example: some 24 hectares of trees were cut down

definition: reduce the size, amount, or quantity of something.
example: I should cut down my sugar intake

definition: prepare a plan, agreement, or other document in detail.
example: they instructed an attorney to draw up a sales agreement

definition: come to a halt.
example: drivers drew up at the lights

definition: make oneself stand in a stiffly upright manner.
example: Sarah drew herself up, full of indignation that he should presume to judge her

definition: discover a fact or piece of information.
example: he hadn't time to find out what was bothering her

definition: have a harmonious or friendly relationship.
example: they seem to get along pretty well

definition: manage to live or survive.
example: don't worry, we'll get along without you

definition: go away, leave.
example: it's time we were getting along

definition: used to express scepticism or disbelief or to tell someone to go away.
example: oh, get along with you!

definition: reach or gain access to something.
example: it's difficult to get at the screws

definition: imply something.
example: I can see what you're getting at

definition: criticize someone subtly and repeatedly.
example: I hope you didn't think I was getting at you

definition: bribe or unfairly influence someone.
example: he had been got at by government officials

definition: escape.
example: Stevie was caught, but the rest of us got away

definition: used to express disbelief or scepticism.
example: ‘I am Spanish.’ ‘Get away.’ ‘I am. I can prove it.’

definition: escape blame, punishment, or undesirable consequences for an act that is wrong.
example: if he thinks he can get away with cheating me, he's very much mistaken

definition: begin to do or give serious attention to something.
example: let's get down to business

definition: perform or make progress in a specified way.
example: how are you getting on?

definition: have a harmonious or friendly relationship.
example: they seem to get on pretty well

definition: be old or comparatively old.
example: we are both getting on a bit

definition: recover from an ailment or an upsetting or startling experience.
example: the trip will help him get over Sal's death

definition: manage to communicate an idea or theory.
example: the company is keen to get the idea over

definition: coax or persuade someone to do or allow something that they initially do not want to.
example: you're not getting round me that easily

definition: deal successfully with a problem.
example: NA

definition: cease making an effort, admit defeat.
example: he wasn't the kind of man to give up easily

definition: allow oneself to be taken over by an emotion or addiction.
example: he gave himself up to pleasure

definition: part with something that one would prefer to keep.
example: they have given up everything for their son

definition: deliver a wanted person to the authorities.
example: Judas gave Jesus up to the Roman soldiers

definition: stop hoping that someone is still going to arrive.
example: oh, it's you—we'd almost given you up

definition: (of a clock) be set to an earlier standard time, especially at the end of summertime.
example: the clocks went back last weekend

definition: (of two people) have known each each for a specified, typically long, period of time.
example: Victor and I go back a long way

definition: support and prevent something from falling.
example: concrete pillars hold up the elevated section of the railway

definition: display something by holding it above one's waist or head.
example: he held up the book so she could see the cover

definition: delay or block the movement or progress of someone or something.
example: our return flight was held up for seven hours

definition: rob someone or something using threats or violence.
example: a masked gunman held up the post office

definition: remain strong or vigorous.
example: the Labour vote held up well

definition: wait, stop.
example: Hold up! I'm coming too!

definition: refrain from playing a winning card for tactical reasons.
example: South held up the Ace until the third round of the suit

definition: regard someone with a feeling of superiority.
example: my mother had social pretensions and looked down on most of our neighbours

definition: await something eagerly.
example: we look forward to seeing you

definition: search for and find a piece of information in a book or database.
example: the translation process amounted to little more than looking up words in bilingual dictionaries

definition: (of a situation) improve.
example: things seemed to be looking up at last

definition: invent a story or plan.
example: she enjoyed making up tall tales

definition: (of parts) compose or constitute a whole.
example: women make up 56 per cent of the student body

definition: compensate for something lost, missed, or deficient.
example: I'll make up the time tomorrow

definition: put together or prepare something from parts or ingredients.
example: make up the mortar to a consistency that can be moulded in the hands

definition: be reconciled after a quarrel.
example: let's kiss and make up

definition: apply cosmetics to oneself or another.
example: ladies will feel like Marlene Dietrich, making themselves up at the dressing tables

definition: take hold of and lift or move someone or something.
example: I reached out and picked up a magazine

definition: go somewhere to collect someone, typically in one's car.
example: will you pick the children up from school?

definition: casually strike up a conversation with a stranger, with the aim of having sex with them.
example: one night I picked up a stranger in a bar

definition: return to a point made by someone in order to criticize it.
example: she picked him up on one niggling point

definition: make someone feel more energetic and cheerful.
example: songs to pick you up and make you feel good

definition: stand up again after a fall.
example: Emily picked herself up off the grass

definition: collect something that has been left elsewhere.
example: Wanda came over to pick up her things

definition: obtain, acquire, or learn something, especially in an informal way.
example: he had picked up a little Russian from his father

definition: become better, improve.
example: my luck's picked up

definition: detect or receive a signal or sound, especially by means of electronic apparatus.
example: we've picked up a distress signal

definition: resume something.
example: let's pick up where we left off yesterday

definition: (of a vehicle) move out from the side of the road, or from its normal position in order to overtake.
example: as he turned the corner a police car pulled out in front of him

definition: withdraw from an undertaking.
example: he was forced to pull out of the championship because of an injury

definition: postpone something.
example: they can't put off a decision much longer

definition: cause someone to lose interest or enthusiasm.
example: she wanted to be a nurse, but the thought of night shifts put her off

definition: distract someone.
example: don't put me off—I'm trying to concentrate

definition: construct or erect something.
example: I put up the tent and cooked a meal

definition: display a notice, sign, or poster.
example: she put up a sign advertising the guest house

definition: increase the cost of something.
example: I'm afraid I've got to put your rent up

definition: provide money as backing for an enterprise.
example: the sponsors are putting up £5,000 for the event

definition: offer or show a particular degree of resistance, effort, or skill in a fight or competitive situation.
example: he put up a brave fight

definition: offer something for sale or auction.
example: the mill was closed and put up for sale

definition: accommodate someone temporarily.
example: we're going to put him up for a few days

definition: propose someone for election or adoption.
example: the party had put up a candidate in each constituency

definition: cause game to rise from cover.
example: the dog almost immediately put up a pheasant

definition: return a sword to its sheath.
example: he put up his sword and gave the body a kick

definition: tolerate or endure something.
example: I'm too tired to put up with any nonsense

definition: collide with someone or something.
example: he ran into a lamp post

definition: reach a level or amount.
example: the company had debts running into millions of dollars

definition: blend into or appear to coalesce with something.
example: her words ran into each other

definition: (of a supply of something) be used up.
example: our food is about to run out

definition: (of rope) be paid out.
example: slowly, he let the cables run out

definition: extend, project.
example: a row of buildings ran out to Whitehall Gate

definition: dismiss a batsman by dislodging the bails with the ball while the batsman is still running between the wickets.
example: NA

definition: emerge from a contest in a specified position.
example: the team ran out 4–1 winners

definition: display someone or something that is a source of pride.
example: her jeans were tight-fitting, showing off her compact figure

definition: boastfully display one's abilities or accomplishments.
example: he was showing off, trying to make a really big impression

definition: resemble a parent or ancestor.
example: the rest of us take after our mother

definition: (of an aircraft or bird) become airborne.
example: the plane took off from the runway

definition: remove clothing from one's or another's body.
example: she took off her cardigan

definition: deduct part of an amount.
example: they took £10 off the bill

definition: choose to have a period away from work.
example: I took the next day off

definition: depart hastily.
example: the officer took off after his men

definition: mimic someone humorously.
example: they kept us all in fits of laughter as they took off their teachers

definition: become interested or engaged in a pursuit.
example: she took up tennis at the age of 11

definition: occupy time, space, or attention.
example: I don't want to take up any more of your time

definition: pursue a matter later or further.
example: he'll have to take it up with the bishop

definition: shorten a garment by turning up the hem.
example: when I got home my grandmother took up the skirt

definition: adopt someone as a student or trainee.
example: he took him up as his assistant

definition: reprimand or scold someone.
example: my parents told me off for coming home late

definition: assign a member of a group to a particular task.
example: there used to be a chap told off every day to fetch us beer

definition: adjust a control on a device to reduce the volume or level.
example: she turned the sound down

definition: reject something offered or proposed.
example: his novel was turned down by publisher after publisher

definition: be used until no longer in good condition or working order.
example: the type was used again and again until it wore out

definition: exhaust someone.
example: an hour of this wandering wore him out
